profiles: Summary Dr. Kameshwar Chandrasekar has worked for over 12 years in EDA tools and methodology development. He has been focusing on improving the productivity of test and verification teams to enable faster delivery of hardware products. He received his Masters and PhD in Computer Engineering from Virginia Tech. He has published 13 research papers in leading international IEEE conferences and holds one patent. His areas of interest include: manufacturing test techniques, DFT, ATPG, RTL validation, formal verification, Silicon debug, algorithms and EDA tool / methodology / solutions development.  Experience Senior Staff Software Engineer Intel Corporation February 2013  – Present (2 years 7 months) Lake Zurich, IL •	4G LTE ERRC feature development for UE capability Category 6 of LTE advanced carrier aggregation.  
•	4G LTE EPDCP, ERLC development based on 3GPP specification 
•	packet traffic manager component to handle the TCP/IP data flow on top of GSM/UMTS/LTE stack, and provide service for IMS application and AP 
•	4G ENAS development 
•	Developed 4G LTE protocol stack feature based on 3GPP specification with C/C++ on Linux. Performed the detailed feature estimation and analysis, design, coding, and thoroughly unit test. 
•	Worked along engineers, testers and product managers in multiple time zones as needed to help integration, field test. Performed detailed analysis on data flow from several protocol layers perspective, identified the root cause of and provided solutions for the last show stopper problems before product launch.  
•	Maintained packet data path components in 4G LTE modem, which handle high speed data transfer. Participated the development to handle large amount of data with minimum CPU usage and low latency. 
•	Authored the LTE protocol stack split on the first Intel Triple-core modem platform. Developed EL2 component from scratch. Participated LTE EPDCP and ERLC changes.  
•	Resolved numerous issues relating to multi-thread, multi-core, improved the throughput performance of the first LTE PS call on Intel 3-Core platform  
 
 Senior Staff Software Engineer Motorola Mobility October 2002  –  February 2013  (10 years 5 months) •	Developed multiple features on Linux based on 3GPP specifications and customer requirements with C++ while working in the 3GSM/LTE protocol stack software development team. Tasks include develop requirement document and feature estimation document, update/maintain software design document, coding, unit test and product after-delivery maintenance support. 
•	Developed Java application to seamless offload the 4G LTE data traffic to WiFi. Responsible for the switch algorithm and GUI notification to the end user. 
•	Developed Java application for Motorola Droid RAZR to find “Best WiFi Link finder” based on the performance for the end user instead of solely based on strength.

•	Significantly contributed the development of Microsoft windows WWAN data connection driver with Microsoft Visual C++ for Motorola Data card.  
•	Worked in an Agile team of 6, developed PSD component of Motorola Aspen platform in C++, which provides communication driver for all packet switch application on top of UMTS and LTE protocol stack.

Summary Carl S. Marshall is a Senior System Architect in the Immersive Computing Lab in Intel Labs, where he leads research efforts in interactive display surfaces, new compute form factors, and novel ways to allow computer interaction. His work, in Interactive Display Surfaces, has been demonstrated across the world through R@I, IDF, and the Creator’s project venues. His current research interest is in immersive computing, graphics architectures, cognitive computing, contextual aware computing, and Internet of Things. In Carl’s 16+ year career at Intel, he started the software driver team for Larrabee, developed novel 3d graphics algorithms in the Intel Architecture Labs, architected the 3d graphics solutions in Consumer Electronics Group, and developed new computer simulations and programming languages. He also co-chaired the Larrabee 1 WarRoom. Carl has 35 patents issued and published several technical papers and book chapters. Carl earned a Masters in Computer Science from Clemson University. Experience Senior System Architect / Research Scientist Intel July 2011  – Present (4 years 2 months) Hillsboro, OR Intel Labs – Immersive Computing Lab  
 
Job Description: Technical lead for the Immersive Computing Lab. Carl drove the vision of making any surface into an interactive display surface. He developed an all-in-one small form factor compute device with a projector, depth camera, and connectivity, client/server architecture that allows any surface/client to talk to any other device (Interactive bowl could interact with Immersive wall), new interactive touch client for planar and non-planar surfaces, programmed iOS and Android app for interacting with display wall, analyzed many depth sensors (structured light, time of flight, and LIDAR), developed ultrasonic proximity sensor via smartphones, and developed Intel Smartroom interactive display surface to automatically allow presenter selection. The “display anywhere” project has been shown in numerous installations across the world through the Creator’s Project, Research@Intel, Intel Developer Forum, CHI 2013, Ted Talks, and on permanent display at Hotel Lucia in Portland, OR. Worked with Business Units on integrated the Labs touch client, display calibration, and developing designs for small form factor compute/display/depth devices. Worked with a clinical psychologist, in the Intel User Experience Lab, on adding emotional expression to enrich the user interaction to the “display anywhere” project.

He developed an all-in-one small form factor compute device with a projector, depth camera, and connectivity, client/server architecture that allows any surface/client to talk to any other device (Interactive bowl could interact with Immersive wall), new interactive touch client for planar and non-planar surfaces, programmed iOS and Android app for interacting with display wall, analyzed many depth sensors (structured light, time of flight, and LIDAR), developed ultrasonic proximity sensor via smartphones, and developed Intel Smartroom interactive display surface to automatically allow presenter selection. The “display anywhere” project has been shown in numerous installations across the world through the Creator’s Project, Research@Intel, Intel Developer Forum, CHI 2013, Ted Talks, and on permanent display at Hotel Lucia in Portland, OR. Worked with Business Units on integrated the Labs touch client, display calibration, and developing designs for small form factor compute/display/depth devices. Worked with a clinical psychologist, in the Intel User Experience Lab, on adding emotional expression to enrich the user interaction to the “display anywhere” project.
